page.title: 03SEA DEFENCE AT PETT LEVEL
page.content: The Southern Water Authority works constantly to prevent lowland{flooding at Pett Level. The beach is made up of rounded flint pebbles which are moved by the littoral drift, west to east, from Pett Level to Rye Harbour entrance. Lorries ply constantly from Rye to Pett Level bringing back loads of beach, 20000 cubic metres every year. In 1932, after a court action was brought to prevent a private citizen fencing off the beach, right of way was established and in 1934 a wooden{sea wall}and slipway were built. In the autumn of 1984 heavy seas flooded a caravan site behind the wall. Now, new defences are being built. A wall of interlocking concrete blocks with steel sheet piling is partly finished, above it will be a curved{wave wall,}a road and a second wall. The cost will be about Â£400,000
